title: Cat. 97  Fragment of a Wall Revetment, late 1st century B.C./1st century A.D.
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Fragment of a Wall Revetment  
Late 1st century B.C./1st century A.D.  
Roman  
Glass, mosaic glass technique; 5.8 × 3.8 × 1.2 cm (2 1/4 × 1 1/2 × 1/2 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.1282

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Translucent dark-emerald-green and deep-greenish-yellow glass. Wall revetment fragment fabricated by the mosaic glass technique, tooled, and polished on the face. The fragment preserves two adjacent oblique sides of an inlay; the top edge appears to be original but may have been grozed or trimmed; the right and bottom edges are broken. In a dark-emerald-green matrix is a mosaic pattern formed from densely packed segments of a single deep-greenish-yellow cane of irregular section.

The fragment is considerably thicker than many of the other examples. The face has been repolished; the edges and back are heavily pitted with a creamy iridescent weathering crust.  
Sidney Goldstein

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 97 Fragment of a Wall Revetment, late 1st century B.C./1st century A.D.

</section>
